Description: Core biological concepts that underpin pathogen genomics are introduced, including microbial structure, function, and classification. The topic establishes a foundation in microbiology‚ covering bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites‚ and explores how genomic variation impacts biology, pathogenicity and virulence.  Key genomic principles such as genome organization, replication, and gene expression are discussed.  Emphasis is placed on the integration of microbiological and genomic perspectives to better understand pathogen behavior, transmission, and adaptation.

Fundamental concepts of how genes and genomic variation are foundational to pathogen genomics. This area explores the structure, function, and regulation of genes in microbial genomes, including how they encode proteins, regulate cellular processes, and respond to environmental pressures. It also examines how variation arises through mutation, recombination, and horizontal gene transfer. These changes contribute to the genetic diversity of pathogens and play critical roles in adaptation, resistance, and evolution. Learners will explore different types of mutations‚ such as SNPs, insertions, deletions, and mobile elements‚ and their functional effects. These insights are essential for interpreting sequence data and linking genotypes to phenotypes in infectious disease contexts.
Short description: Foundational concepts of pathogen genomics and genetic variation.
Remember: Identify the fundamental concepts of genomics, including the basic structure of genes and the types of genomic variation (K)
Understand: Explain the structure of genes, genomic variation, and their influence on pathogen behaviour (K)
Apply: Use knowledge of gene structure and genetic variation to infer function (K)
Analyse: Examine the structure and function of genes and genomic variations that drive disease mechanisms.(K)
Evaluate: Evaluate the functional impacts of genomic structure and genetic variation on infectious disease pathology (K)
Create: Design innovative approaches to apply genomic knowledge to study biological and disease mechanisms (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Biological and resistance mechanisms of pathogens
Description: Biological processes, host interactions, and resistance mechanisms of infectious pathogens, focusing on their molecular and cellular biology, and how they adapt and survive in various environments. It covers the structure, function, and lifecycle of infectious agents (bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites), the mechanisms they use to invade hosts and evade defenses, and how these processes contribute to disease or environmental impact. The topic also examines genetic and biochemical pathways driving resistance, such as mutations, horizontal gene transfer, and adaptation to selective pressures. By integrating these areas, learners gain a comprehensive understanding of how pathogens interact with hosts or ecosystems, develop resistance, and influence broader biological systems.
Short description: Processes involving how infectious pathogens adapt, interact with their environments, and develop resistance through biological and genetic mechanisms.
Remember: Recall key facts and concepts about pathogens, including their structures, life cycles, and the ways they resist antimicrobial treatments.(K)
Understand: Explain how pathogens interact with their hosts and the ways they develop resistance to drugs or treatments.(K)
Apply: Use knowledge of pathogen biology and resistance to predict patterns of infection or resistance in different scenarios.(K,S)
Analyse: Examine how pathogen biology, host factors, and resistance mechanisms work together to influence the progression of infectious diseases.(S)
Evaluate: Critically assess current knowledge of  pathogen-host interactions, disease and resistance mechanisms, identifying gaps or limitations.(K)
Create: Develop approaches to describe how infectious pathogens adapt and evolve over time and their impact on disease and treatment (K,S)

Description: Pathogenicity and virulence refer to a pathogen's ability to cause disease and the severity of the disease. This topic explores the genetic and molecular determinants that enable pathogens to invade hosts, evade immune responses, and inflict cellular damage. Learners will examine virulence factors such as toxins, adhesion molecules, secretion systems, and mechanisms of immune evasion, all of which contribute to disease outcomes. The topic also includes the role of genomics in identification of virulence-associated genes and understand how these elements differ among strains and species. These insights support the development of diagnostic tools, therapeutic targets, and infectious disease surveillance strategies.
Short description: Factors that cause disease and it severity.
Remember: Define pathogenicity and virulence (K)
Understand: Describe how pathogenic elements and virulence factors contribute to pathogen epidemiology (K)
Apply: Apply knowledge of pathogenicity and virulence in assessing disease risk and  in infection control practices. (K,S)
Analyse: Differentiate between microbes based on their pathogenicity and virulence profiles. (K)
Evaluate: Measure the impact of pathogenic elements and virulence factors on disease outcomes and infection control practices (S)
Create: Design innovative approaches for investigating infectious microbes' pathogenicity and virulence. (K,S)

Description: Sample preparation and processing involve the technical steps required to generate high-quality input material for sequencing and analysis. This topic includes guidance on sample collection, transport, storage, and biosafety procedures, especially for clinical or field settings. It covers nucleic acid extraction and quantification techniques that ensure the integrity and quality of DNA or RNA for sequencing. The topic also addresses common challenges such as contamination and degradation, and provides best practices to minimize these risks. A well-executed preparation protocol is critical for accurate and reproducible genomic results.

Ethical considerations and consent processes specific to the collection and preparation of biological samples for genomics applications in infectious diseases. Emphasis is on  ensuring respect for individual rights, privacy, and cultural contexts while obtaining samples for clinical, public health, or research purposes. Key considerations include informed consent tailored to sample collection, transparency in communicating the purpose and use of samples, and addressing ethical challenges during collection in outbreak or vulnerable settings. The topic also highlights practices that ensure fairness in how samples are collected, processed, and used for diagnostics, disease surveillance, or research.
Short description: Ethical principles and consent processes needed to collect and prepare biological samples for genomics in infectious diseases, ensuring respect for individual rights.
Remember: Recall the ethical principles and consent requirements specific to sample collection and preparation in genomics for infectious diseases.(K)
Understand: Recall ethical principles, regulations, and guidelines for sample collection and preparation in genomics applications for infectious diseases.(K)
Apply: Apply ethical considerations to collection and processing samples and related data for genomic analysis (K)
Analyse: Analyse ethical dilemmas related to sample collection and processing for genomic analysis (K)
Evaluate: Critically assess whether a sample collection and preparation process upholds ethical standards, balancing individual rights with the demands of genomics research or public health (K).
Create: Design an ethically sound and culturally sensitive protocol for the collection and preparation of biological samples for genomic applications focused on infectious agents and disease management (K)

Description: Collection of samples for microbiological testing, molecular diagnostics, and genomic analysis, emphasising techniques that ensure the integrity and reliability of samples for downstream applications. The topic  encompasses the collection of various specimen types, such as blood, swabs, tissues, and environmental samples, while adhering to microbiological best practices, including aseptic techniques and contamination prevention. It  highlights the importance of matching sample collection methods to specific analytical needs, such as pathogen isolation, nucleic acid extraction, or genomic sequencing and  addresses the procedural and safety considerations required to maintain the quality of microbial samples, ensuring their suitability for accurate identification, characterisation, and analysis
Short description: Principles and practices for collecting samples for microbiological and molecular testing, and genomic analysis.
Remember: Recall key methods, tools, and protocols used to collect samples for microbiological, molecular, and genomic analyses (K).
Understand: Explain the importance of proper sample collection techniques to maintain the quality and integrity of specimens for microbiological and genomic analysis (K)
Apply: Apply appropriate techniques to collect and handle samples for specific diagnostic or genomic purposes (S).
Analyse: Analyse factors that affect the quality and suitability of samples for microbiological and genomic workflows (K).
Evaluate: Critically evaluate sample collection protocols to ensure they meet the requirements for microbiological testing, molecular diagnostics, and genomic analyses (K).
Create: Design a sample collection strategy that ensures the integrity and appropriateness of samples for microbiological, molecular, and genomic analyses (K,S).

Description: Preservation of  biological samples for microbiological testing, molecular diagnostics, and genomic analysis, ensuring their integrity and suitability for downstream applications. it covers the principles and methods for stabilising samples to prevent degradation of microorganisms, nucleic acids, or proteins, including the use of appropriate storage media, temperature conditions, and transport practices. learners will explore how preservation techniques vary depending on the sample type (e.g., blood, swabs, tissues, environmental specimens) and the intended analysis. The  topic also addresses challenges such as maintaining viability for microbial cultures, preventing nucleic acid degradation for molecular and genomic studies, and complying with biosafety standards during sample handling and storage.
Short description: Methods and principles for preserving biological samples to maintain their integrity for microbiological, molecular, and genomic analyses.
Remember: Recall key methods and conditions used to preserve samples for microbiological, molecular, and genomic applications.(K)
Understand: Explain the importance of sample preservation in maintaining the viability and integrity of specimens for accurate downstream testing. (K)
Apply: Apply appropriate preservation techniques to maintain the integrity of different types of microbiological samples.(S)
Analyse: Analyse factors that influence the effectiveness of preservation methods for different sample types and analyses.(S)
Evaluate: Appraise sample preservation protocols to ensure they align with the requirements of microbiological, molecular, or genomic workflows.(S)
Create: Design a sample preservation strategy tailored to specific microbiological or genomic applications, ensuring sample stability and compliance with best practices.(K,S)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Sample preparation for pathogen detection and analysis
Description: Preparation of  biological and environmental samples for detecting and analysing pathogens using microbiological, biochemical, and molecular techniques. Topic includes processes such as  pathogen isolation and enrichment, sample homogenisation, and preparation for diagnostic assays (e.g., culture, antigen-based testing, microscopy). Key  considerations include preventing contamination, optimising sample integrity, and ensuring the suitability of prepared samples for pathogen identification and characterization. The aim is to generate reliable and actionable data on pathogen presence, type, and characteristics for applications in clinical diagnostics, research, and public health.
Short description: Methods for preparing samples to detect and analyse pathogens through microbiological, biochemical, and molecular tests.
Remember: Recall methods used for sample preparation in pathogen detection (e.g. filtration, centrifugation, or selective culturing for isolating pathogens).(K)
Understand: Explain the importance of sample preparation techniques, such as enrichment methods, and identify the most suitable approach for specific pathogen detection scenarios.(K)
Apply: Apply appropriate sample preparation methods based on the type of pathogen and detection technique (S).
Analyse: Analyse potential issues in sample preparation that could affect pathogen detection accuracy (S)
Evaluate: Critically evaluate the effectiveness of sample preparation techniques and their impact on the accuracy and reliability of pathogen detection results (S)
Create: Design a sample preparation workflow for detecting specific pathogens in complex samples (K,S)

Description: Preparation of biological samples for genomic analysis, emphasising high-quality nucleic acid (dna/rna) extraction. It includes processes such as cell lysis, nucleic acid isolation, purification, and preparation of sequencing libraries. Key considerations include preventing degradation, removing inhibitors, and ensuring the integrity and concentration of nucleic acids.
Short description: Techniques for preparing high-quality DNA or RNA from biological samples for genomic analysis.
Remember: Recall key steps and tools used in nucleic acid preparation for genomic analysis.(K)
Understand: Describe the importance of each step in the sample preparation process and how it influences the quality of genomic analysis (K)
Apply: Execute standard protocols for sample preparation, ensuring proper handling and optimisation of nucleic acid quality for genomic workflows.(S)
Analyse: Examine sample preparation outputs and determine factors that impact suitability of genomic samples for downstream applications.(S)
Evaluate: Critically evaluate the effectiveness of sample preparation techniques  for various types of samples and their impact on genomic analysis outputs (S)
Create: Develop a comprehensive sample preparation protocol tailored for a specific genomic analysis technique, integrating best practices and innovations (K, S)

Description: Specimen Quality Control (QC) involves assessing the quality and integrity of biological samples to ensure their suitability for downstream applications such as microbiological testing, molecular diagnostics, and sequencing. This topic focuses on methods for evaluating critical quality attributes, including the viability of microorganisms, the integrity and purity of nucleic acids, and the absence of contaminants or inhibitors. Key areas include the use of analytical tools like spectrophotometry, fluorometry, gel electrophoresis, and microbial culture techniques to assess sample adequacy. It also emphasises the importance of implementing quality checkpoints during collection, transport, storage, and preparation to minimize degradation and variability. Specimen QC is essential to ensure reliability, reproducibility, and accuracy of results.
Short description: Methods for  ensuring that  biological samples meet the required standards for accurate and reliable testing in microbiology, molecular diagnostics, and genomics.
Remember: Recall the key parameters and methods used to assess the quality of samples from collection to sequencing.(K)
Understand: Explain the importance of specimen quality control in ensuring reliable and reproducible results for pathogen detection and downstream genomic applications. (K)
Apply: Apply appropriate QC methods to evaluate and validate the quality of biological specimens for testing or genomic analysis.(S)
Analyse: Interpret QC results to ensure sample quality and suitability for microbiological, molecular, or genomic workflows.(S)
Evaluate: Critique the adequacy of a QC protocols in ensuring the reliability and consistency of sample analysis.(S)
Create: Design a robust QC workflow tailored to the specific requirements of microbiological, molecular, or genomic analyses.(K)

Description: Linking samples to data involves establishing and maintaining accurate connections between biological specimens, their associated metadata, and the results generated from microbiological, molecular, and genomic analyses. This topic focuses on methods for ensuring traceability and integrity throughout the data generation pipeline, from sample collection to final analysis. Learners will explore strategies for using unique sample identifiers, integrating laboratory information management systems (LIMS), and adhering to data management standards to ensure reproducibility and accountability. Emphasis is on the  importance of linking samples to data in clinical, research, and public health contexts, facilitating data sharing, collaborative studies, and informed decision-making.
Short description: Addresses the importance and provides approaches of accurately linking biological samples to metadata and results in microbiological, molecular, and genomic workflows.
Remember: Recall the approaches and metadata fields used for linking samples to their associated data and results.(K)
Understand: Explain the importance of sample-data linkage for ensuring data traceability, reproducibility, and collaborative (genomic) data analysis.(K)
Apply: Use bioinformatics tools or databases (e.g., LIMS, sequencing platforms) to associate samples with corresponding (genomic) data.(S)
Analyse: Review linked metadata and tracking systems to identify potential gaps and inconsistencies in linking specimens with their data. (K, S)
Evaluate: Assess the robustness and compliance of data linkage and management workflows and practices to ensure samples are accurately linked to their results. (K,S)
Create: Design a comprehensive framework for linking samples to data, ensuring traceability and reproducibility in microbiological, molecular, and genomic analyses.(S)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: 3. Sample Analysis and Genomic Data Generation
Description: End-to-end laboratory and analytical processes involved in transforming pathogen samples into high-quality genomic data. It brings together foundational and advanced techniques that underpin genomic investigations, and includes microbiological and molecular approaches  ensuring that samples meet the quality requirements for downstream applications.

Foundational microbiological methods and techniques used to isolate, identify, and study microorganisms. It includes traditional techniques such as culturing, staining, microscopy, biochemical assays, and advanced approaches like microbial quantification and susceptibility testing. emphasis is placed on aseptic techniques, media preparation, and microbial growth conditions to ensure accurate results. These methods are essential for characterising microbial diversity, detecting pathogenic organisms, supporting diagnostics, providing critical insights into response to antimicrobial agents.
Short description: Techniques for isolating and identifying microorganisms  using classical and modern microbiological methods such as  culturing, microscopy, and biochemical techniques.
Remember: Recall key microbiological methods and techniques for culturing, typing, and susceptibility testing (K)
Understand: Describe the steps and purposes of culturing microorganisms, typing methods, and susceptibility testing (K)
Apply: Perform microbiological techniques such as culturing microorganisms, typing, and testing for antimicrobial resistance. (S)
Analyse: Interpret results from culturing, typing, and susceptibility tests to determine microbial identity and resistance. (S)
Evaluate: Evaluate test accuracy and reliability through quality control, assessing strengths and limitations of different microbiological methods.(K)
Create: Create protocols to improve accuracy and efficiency in microbial analysis for specific research or clinical needs.(K)

Description: Quality control (QC) processes covering specific standards and protocols used to assess nucleic acid integrity, concentration (yield), and levels of contamination prior to sequencing, ensuring samples meet platform-specific requirements that are essential for generating high-quality sequencing data. Learners will review methods such as fluorometric quantification, electrophoretic profiling (e.g., TapeStation, Bioanalyzer), and spectrophotometric ratios, and will understand explore the implications of sample degradation or contamination on sequencing success. The topic also introduces QC measures applied to sequencing libraries, such as size distribution analysis, adapter dimers, and library multiplexing balance, which are critical for achieving even data distribution across samples in high-throughput sequencing runs. Familiarity with QC indicators(3) enables learners to maintain consistency and reliability in genomics workflows.
Short description: Sequencing-specific QC to assess DNA integrity, yield, and library balance for high-quality data generation.
Remember: Recall standards and protocols for QC testing of DNA integrity, yield, and library multiplex balancing (K)
Understand: Describe the processes and methods used for QC testing of biological material for genome sequencing and explain their importance.(K)
Apply: Perform QC testing such as measuring DNA integrity, quantifying yield, and assessing library balance to ensure biological sample quality and integrity for sequencing methodologies (S)
Analyse: Interpret QC metrics to ensure that sample material meets sequencing standards.(K,S) (add info on examples on DNA integrity, quantifying yield, and assessing library balance, to clarify this is pre-sequencing)
Evaluate: Critique the accuracy of QC testing methods and evaluate the strengths and limitations of techniques for ensuring DNA quality and yield.(K)
Create: Design solutions to address common issues and optimize the preparation of high-quality samples for sequencing.(K)

Description: Molecular-based techniques are essential tools for detecting and analysing biological molecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins. This topic covers commonly used methods including polymerase chain reaction (PCR), quantitative PCR (qPCR), reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR), and hybridization techniques. Learners also explore modern tools such as CRISPR, isothermal amplification, and microarrays, which enhance sensitivity and specificity in pathogen detection, genotyping, and molecular profiling. These techniques are widely applied in diagnostics, surveillance, and research.
Short description: Molecular approaches  used to detect, amplify, and analyse pathogen genetic material.
Remember: Recall fundamental principles and terminology related to molecular-based techniques (K)
Understand: Describe the processes and applications of various molecular techniques for detecting and analysing pathogen samples(K)
Apply: Perform standard molecular assays for pathogen detection and analysis. (S)
Analyse: Interpret data generated from molecular techniques to characterise specific pathogens (S)
Evaluate: Critique the accuracy and reliability of molecular techniques in pathogen genomics, evaluating their strengths and limitations for diagnostics and epidemiology.(K)
Create: Design advanced molecular protocols to diagnose diseases, identify resistance genes, and guide public health. (K)

Description: End-to-end laboratory workflow approaches used to generation raw sequence data from nucleic acid samples. It includes an overview of different sequencing platforms (e.g., Illumina, Nanopore), their capabilities, and their suitability for different applications. Learners will examine the steps involved in library preparation, sequencing runs, and initial quality control. The focus is on understanding the principles of high-throughput sequencing and how choices made during sequencing setup impact data quality, coverage, and downstream analysis. This knowledge is essential for interpreting outputs and troubleshooting experimental protocols in genomics labs.
Short description: Methods and applications of genome sequencing, including workflows and platforms.
Remember: Recall the basics and terminology of genome sequencing methods and technologies. (K)
Understand: Describe genome sequencing methods, workflows, strengths, and limitations.(K)
Apply: Use genome sequencing technologies to generate data, implementing protocols for sample preparation, library construction, and sequencing. (S)
Analyse: Select the best sequencing methods for applications, and examine output quality (K)
Evaluate: Critique sequencing methods for accuracy, throughput, cost, and suitability, identifying strengths and limitations in research and healthcare (K)
Create: Design experimental workflows using advanced sequencing technologies (S)

Description: Workflows for detecting, identifying, and characterising infectious agents in patient samples to support evidence-based clinical decision-making from sample collection, laboratory methods to  integration of quality control, turnaround time, data interpretation, and reporting within a diagnostic workflow. Additionally, the topic highlights the growing importance of standardised workflows, automation, and clinical bioinformatics in improving the speed, reliability, and clinical utility of diagnostic outputs across diverse healthcare settings.  Learners will explore how diagnostic strategies are selected based on clinical context, pathogen type, and urgency, ensuring that results are timely, accurate, and actionable.
Short description: Integrated diagnostic workflows combining microbiological and genomic methods to support accurate, timely detection and characterisation of pathogens in clinical care.
Remember: List microbiological, molecular or genomic techniques used for clinical diagnostics of specific pathogens.(K)
Understand: Explain the role of various diagnostic techniques in identifying specific pathogens and guiding clinical decisions. (K)
Apply: Utilise appropriate diagnostic methods to identify pathogens and for effective disease management (S)
Analyse: Analyse diagnostic results to interpret pathogen characteristics to inform treatment and downstream management.(S)
Evaluate: Assess the applicability of diagnostic tools in various clinical scenarios (K,S).
Create: Design a diagnostic workflow tailored to specific clinical needs, integrating appropriate microbiological, molecular and genomic approaches.(S)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: 4. Genomic Data Workflows, Analysis and Integration
Description: Methods used to process,  refine raw genomic information, analysis and integration with other datasets  support various applications.

Genomic data repositories in pathogen genomics are specialised databases that store, manage, and provide access to genomic data related to pathogens. They consist of standardised pathogen genomic data, structured organization with sample metadata integration, open and controlled access, standardised submission and curation, multi-omics integration, and tools and resources for data analysis. These repositories facilitate comprehensive data analysis and integration while adhering to appropriate ethical and data-sharing principles.
Short description: Specialised databases that store, manage, and provide access to pathogen genomic data, supporting comprehensive analysis and integration while adhering to standardised practices, ethics, and data-sharing principles.
Remember: List specific pathogen genomic data repositories relevant for routine applications in research, patient management and public health (K).
Understand: Outline how genomic data repositories can be used and summarise the benefits of these in pathogen genomics  Describe the key functions of genomic data repositories and their importance for data analysis and integration.(K).
Apply: Utilise data  repositories relevant to pathogen genomics . Use genomic repositories to manage, integrate, and analyse pathogen data. (S)
Analyse: Maintain data  repositories relevant to pathogen genomics to comply with applicable data standards.  Interpret the results obtained from genomic data analysis using repository tools.(S)
Evaluate: Evaluate data repositories relevant to pathogen genomics including compliance with applicable data standards (S)
Create: Design and improve data repositories relevant to pathogen genomics ensuring compliance with applicable data standards (K,S).

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic data analysis methods, tools and software
Description: This topic covers the foundational principles, tools and techniques involved in pathogen genomic data analysis emphasising bioinformatics software, statistical models, and computational approaches. It covers key bioinformatics tools, alongside the algorithms and methods used for sequence alignment, variant calling,  genome assembly, gene and allelic annotation, phylogenetic analysis, and functional annotation. The primary focus is on understanding and applying individual tools and methods, rather than assembling them into complete analytical workflows. Scientists working in this area develop expertise in selecting the right computational tools, interpreting results, and optimising pathogen genomic analysis for accuracy and efficiency.
Short description: Tools and methods emphasising individual software, statistical models, and computational approaches rather than full workflows.
Remember: Identify key bioinformatics tools, algorithms, and software used in pathogen genomic data analysis, including their core functions and applications.(K)
Understand: Discuss commonly used methods, tools and software for pathogen genomics data (K)
Apply: Implement appropriate tools to analyse pathogen genomic data, ensuring correct application of methods for sequence processing, variant identification, and annotation (S)
Analyse:
Interpret the outputs of different analytical methods and software in pathogen genomics, assessing their computational approaches, strengths, and limitations..
(K)
Evaluate: Evaluate the effectiveness and suitability of pathogen genomics analysis methods and software by assessing their accuracy, reproducibility, and computational efficiency. Justify their application for specific questions.(K)
Create: Design and implement an optimised bioinformatics workflow or tool to enhance pathogen genomic analysis, addressing gaps in current methodologies and improving their efficiency in various applications(S)

Description: Involves structuring and executing genomic data analysis pipelines, providing a step-by-step approach to processing pathogen sequencing data. It covers quality control, key file formats such as FASTQ, BAM, and VCF, ensuring proper data handling from raw sequencing reads to variant calling and annotation. Workflow automation tools like Nextflow, and Galaxy are integral to streamlining and standardising analyses. The emphasis is on building structured workflows that transform raw sequencing data into actionable insights, ensuring reproducibility, scalability, and efficiency in pathogen genomic research.
Short description: How genomic analysis tools are combined into structured workflows and pipelines to process and analyse genomic data effectively
Remember: Recognize the key steps in pathogen genomic data workflows, including file formats (FASTQ, BAM, VCF), sequence processing, and quality control. (K).
Understand: Explain automated workflow steps in pathogen genomic sequence data analysis workflows. (K)
Apply: Execute a pathogen genomic data analysis pipeline, performing data preprocessing, quality control ....and analysis. (????) using workflow automation tools. (S)
Analyse: Examine outputs of a genomic workflow to ensure data accuracy, quality and reliability (K,S)
Evaluate: Evaluate the scalability, performance, and applicability of pathogen genomics workflows in different contexts (e.g. outbreak response, antimicrobial resistance tracking, and genomic epidemiology)(K).
Create: Develop a customized, automated pathogen genomics workflow that integrates multiple tools and ensures reproducibility, scalability, and high-quality output   (K,S).

Description: This topic focuses on the application of statistical methods in pathogen genomics to analyse and interpret data in the context of infectious diseases. It covers foundational concepts such as data variability, probability, and statistical models, emphasizing their use in identifying genomic variants, understanding pathogen evolution, and tracking transmission patterns. Learners will explore the role of statistical genomics in antimicrobial resistance (AMR) studies, outbreak investigations, and vaccine design. The topic highlights the integration of statistical approaches with genomic and epidemiological data
Short description: Covers statistical methods for analysing and interpreting genomic data in infectious diseases
Remember: Recall foundational statistical methods used in pathogen genomics (e.g. regression analysis and hypothesis testing) (K)
Understand: Describe key statistical methods including data quality control, normalization, summary metrics and explain their importance in genomic data analysis (K).
Apply: Apply appropriate metrics and methods to genomic data to discover and visualise patterns (K)
Analyse: Examine statistical outputs to interpret genomic data and identify trends (K)
Evaluate: Recommend and evaluate statistical methods for pathogen genomics, addressing limitations and suggesting improvements to genomic data analysis (K)
Create: Design statistical workflows to analyse and integrate genomic and epidemiological data for infectious diseases (K)

Description: This topic focuses on the principles, tools, and methods for constructing phylogenetic trees from genomic data. Learners will explore key steps in the analytical workflow, including sequence alignment, model selection, and tree-building algorithms (e.g., maximum likelihood, Bayesian inference). The topic emphasises understanding the computational processes, selecting appropriate methods for specific datasets, and ensuring tree accuracy and reliability. It provides the foundation for conducting phylogenetic analyses as part of genomic workflows
Short description: Analytical methods and computational workflows used to construct phylogenetic trees from genomic data
Remember: Define phylogenetics and list the key steps and tools used in phylogenetic analysis workflows (K)
Understand: Explain the principles behind phylogenetic tree construction and model selection (K)
Apply: Apply phylogenetic analysis methods to construct trees from aligned genomic data (S)
Analyse: Analyse how alignment quality and model choice affect the reliability of phylogenetic trees (K)
Evaluate: Assess the accuracy and robustness of a phylogenetic tree in representing evolutionary relationships (K)
Create: Design a workflow for constructing phylogenetic trees tailored to specific genomic datasets (K)

Description: Phylogeography in pathogen genomics combines phylogenetic and geographical data to study the spatial distribution of genetic lineages of pathogens. This helps to understand the historical and contemporary processes influencing the spread and evolution of pathogens, providing insights for public health and disease control. Terminologies include genetic lineages, migration, and dispersal. Phylogeography combines geographic information with phylogenetic and population genomic approaches to infer the evolutionary history of species or populations within a geographic context. This approach has been instrumental in understanding the emergence, spread, and evolution of various plant pathogens. Specifically, phylogeography can address questions about the origin of a pathogen, whether it is native or introduced, and the timing and frequency of its introductions. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33021879/
Short description: Combines phylogenetic to visualise geographical distribution. (add a proper definition)
Remember: Define phylogeography terminology and methods used in research and public health (K).
Understand: Explain phylogeographic approaches, methods and tools used to understand evolution and spread or pathogens and disease in a geographical context (K).
Apply: Use phylogeographic methods on pathogen genomic data to track emergence, spread, and evolution.(S).
Analyse: Analyse genomic data with phylogeographic methods to determine pathogen evolution and geographic distribution, and study factors affecting their spread. (S).
Evaluate: Evaluate the quality and relevance of phylogeographic data and methods, validating findings for various applications. (K)
Create: Innovate phylogeographic methods to enhance understanding the emergence, spread, and evolution of pathogens (K)

Description: This topic focuses on the theoretical principles and analytical methods of metagenomics, the study of genetic material recovered directly from environmental or clinical samples without the need for culturing organisms. In the context of infectious diseases, metagenomics enables the identification and characterization of complex microbial communities, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites, in a single sample. This topic emphasises foundational concepts such as microbial diversity, functional genomics, and computational approaches for analysing metagenomic data. Learners will explore applications of metagenomics in diagnosing infections, monitoring antimicrobial resistance (AMR), tracking outbreaks, and studying pathogen evolution.
Short description: Explores the principles and methods of metagenomics for analysing microbial communities in environmental and mixed samples.
Remember: Recall the foundational principles and key terms related to metagenomics and define appropriate data types suitable for metagenomics (K)
Understand: Explain the role of metagenomics in providing insights into microbial diversity and functional potential across diverse sample types. (K)
Apply: Use metagenomic tools to analyse microbial communities in various samples. (S)
Analyse: Interpret metagenomic data to identify patterns in microbial diversity, resistance, or functional relevance (S)
Evaluate: Assess the suitability and limitations of metagenomic approaches for different research, clinical or public health questions (K)
Create: Design metagenomic workflows tailored to specific research or surveillance objectives. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Integration of epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data
Description: Integration of epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data entails combining information from three distinct but complementary sources to provide a comprehensive understanding of infectious diseases. Epidemiological data (population level data from surveillance, patterns and trends); Lab data (clinical diagnostic tests, pathogen identification, subtyping and resistance profiles); Genomic data (sequence information, genetic variations). Integration helps with comprehensive analysis, enhanced surveillance, informed decision-making etc… Applications where integration is used include outbreak investigation, AMR monitoring, treatment decisions, public health policy. Integrating diverse data types, the overall goal is to improve public health outcomes through more precise, timely, and effective responses to infectious diseases.
Short description: Combining information from various data sources for comprehensive insights.
Remember: List methods to integrate epidemiological, laboratory and genomic data in pathogen genomics in healthcare (K)
Understand: Describe the processes and techniques for integrating epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data, highlighting the significance of each step.(K)
Apply: Implement appropriate methods and tools to effectively integrate epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data. (K,S)
Analyse: Review results from combining epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data.(K)
Evaluate: Evaluate methods for integrating epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data and identifying areas for improvement.(K)
Create: Develop and adapt methods to integrate and derive inferences from epidemiological, laboratory, and genomic data to enhance infectious disease tracking, prevention, and control.(K)

Description: Data interpretation bridges analysis and decision-making by tanslating  genomic data into actionable insights for healthcare and public health.

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Interpretation pipeline from sequence qc to application
Description: This topic provides a dual focus on the theoretical principles and practical workflows involved in genomic data interpretation, covering the full pipeline from sequence quality control (QC) to actionable applications. The theoretical perspective emphasizes understanding the rationale, principles, and challenges underlying each stage of the pipeline, such as sequence QC, alignment, variant calling, annotation, and functional interpretation. Building on this foundation, the practical perspective explores how these concepts are operationalised through tools and workflows to ensure the reliability and accuracy of results. Together, these approaches equip learners with the knowledge to critically assess, design, and apply genomic pipelines in diverse contexts, including clinical diagnostics, public health surveillance, and research.
Short description: Theoretical principles and practical workflows of genomic interpretation pipelines, from sequence QC to actionable insights in diagnostics, research, and public health.
Remember: Outline the theoretical principles and key practical steps in a genomic interpretation pipeline from sequence quality control to actionable results. (K)
Understand: Explain how concepts such as QC metrics, alignment algorithms, statistical models, and functional annotation underpin practical workflows in genomic data analysis, enabling accurate interpretation and application.(K)
Apply: Apply appropriate tools and workflows to interpret genomic data for actionable results for specific data types and applications.(S)
Analyse: Relate the steps and processes at each stage of the interpretation pipeline, from sequence QC to application, to their impact on the accuracy and reliability of genomic insights.(K)
Evaluate: Critique the design of a genomic interpretation pipeline to determine its robustness and applicability to specific contexts (K)
Create: Design an analytical framework for a genomic interpretation pipeline tailored to specific data types and applications (K,S)

Description: This topic focuses on understanding and interpreting quality control (QC) metrics generated during genomic workflows to ensure the reliability and accuracy of sequencing data. It covers the key metrics used to assess the quality of raw sequencing reads, such as base quality scores, GC content, sequencing depth, and error rates. Learners will explore how to evaluate these metrics to identify potential issues, such as contamination, poor sequencing quality, or technical biases, and their impact on downstream analyses. The topic emphasizes the importance of interpreting QC metrics within the context of specific applications, such as variant calling, genome assembly, or metagenomics, ensuring that data meets the requirements for accurate biological and clinical insights.
Short description: Interpretation of genomic quality control metrics to assess data reliability and suitability for downstream analyses
Remember: List the essential quality control (QC) metrics used to assess genome sequence data quality.(K)
Understand: Describe the purpose and importance of genomic QC metrics in evaluating sequencing data quality. (K) .
Apply: Apply QC metrics to evaluate the quality of sequencing data and identify potential issues. (S)
Analyse: Examine genomic data QC metrics to determine patterns, inconsistencies, or potential issues  that could impact genomic workflows and applications.(K)
Evaluate: Review and assess QC reports to ensure data quality meets the requirements of downstream genomic analyses. (K)
Create: Design a strategy for interpreting QC metrics to optimise data quality for specific genomic applications. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Interpretation of speciation and strain typing results
Description: This topic focuses on understanding and interpreting results from speciation and strain typing analyses, which are critical for identifying, characterising, and differentiating microbial species and strains. Speciation involves determining the specific identity of microorganisms, while strain typing helps distinguish between strains of the same species to assess genetic variation, epidemiology, or outbreak origins. Learners will explore the principles underlying common speciation and typing methods (e.g., MALDI-TOF, genome sequencing, multilocus sequence typing [MLST], pulsed-field gel electrophoresis [PFGE]), and how to interpret their outputs. The topic emphasises using these results to infer relationships between microorganisms, track disease transmission, and guide clinical, public health, and research applications.
Short description: Interpreting microbial speciation and strain typing results  to identify and distinguish different species and strains of pathogens
Remember: Define speciation and strain typing and recall the methods and techniques used for these processes in the context of microbial genomes.(K)
Understand: Describe how speciation and strain typing reveal microbial diversity and outbreak sources through genetic differences.(K)
Apply: Use speciation and typing methods to infer microbial identity and relationships (e.g identifying clonal links during outbreaks).(S)
Analyse: Examine speciation and strain typing outputs to identify patterns or discrepancies in microbial identification or strain differentiation.(K,S)
Evaluate: Assess the utility of strain typing results for addressing a clinical or epidemiological problem. (K)
Create: Develop a framework for integrating speciation and strain typing results into decision-making for clinical, public health, or research applications. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Interpretation of phylogenetic trees in the context of genomic epidemiology
Description: This topic focuses on interpreting phylogenetic trees to infer evolutionary relationships and draw insights relevant to genomic epidemiology. Learners will explore how to analyse tree topology, branch lengths, and clustering patterns to identify sources of outbreaks, track pathogen transmission, and monitor evolutionary trends such as the emergence of drug resistance. The topic emphasizes integrating phylogenetic results with epidemiological metadata, such as geographic or temporal data, to support public health decision-making and research.
Short description: Interpreting phylogenetic trees to understand evolutionary relationships and epidemiological dynamics in genomic studies.
Remember: Define key terms and recall components used in phylogenetic tree interpretation.(K)
Understand: Illustrate the significance of phylogenetic tree features in understanding pathogen evolution and transmission.(K)
Apply: Apply phylogenetic tree interpretations to infer pathogen spread and evolutionary trends.(S)
Analyse: Examine tree structures to identify genetic relationships, epidemiological clusters, and the source of outbreaks. (KS)
Evaluate: Assess the relevance of phylogenetic tree interpretations for epidemiological conclusions e.g. hypothesised source of an outbreak (K)
Create: Develop approaches for integrating phylogenetic tree interpretations with epidemiological metadata. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genetic relatedness thresholds and typing schemes in genomic epidemiology studies
Description: This topic focuses on interpreting genetic relatedness thresholds and typing scheme results to infer relationships among microbial isolates. Learners will explore metrics like SNP distances and typing schemes like wgMLST and SNP typing to define clusters, identify transmission links, and support outbreak investigations.
Short description: Using genetic relatedness thresholds and typing schemes to classify microbial isolates and infer their relationships
Remember: Define key terms and recall metrics for assessing genetic relatedness.(K)
Understand: Explain the concepts of genetic relatedness thresholds and how they inform pathogen clustering.(K)
Apply: Execute the interpretation of relatedness thresholds to classify microbial clusters. (e.g. using SNP thresholds to identify clusters)(S)
Analyse: Examine relatedness thresholds to detect genetic relationships between isolates and infer transmission chains. (KS)
Evaluate: Assess the suitability of typing schemes and relatedness thresholds for outbreak investigations, ensuring they provide adequate resolution for specific scenarios.(K)
Create: Develop new or improved typing schemes and relatedness thresholds for enhanced genomic epidemiology studies.(K,S)

Description: Using genomic data and techniques to identify, trace, and understand the spread of infectious diseases during an outbreak.
Short description: Using genomic data and techniques to identify, trace, and understand the spread of infectious diseases during an outbreak.
Remember: Recall terminology and components of genomic data used in outbreak and surveillance studies (e.g. SNP matrices, metadata).(K)
Understand: Illustrate the role of genomic data interpretation in identifying outbreak dynamics. (K)
Apply: Demonstrate how to interpret genomic data for outbreak investigations. (e.g. wgMLST to link cases in an outbreak).(S)
Analyse: Analyse genomic data from outbreak investigations to identify patterns, common sources, and transmission dynamics of pathogens (K)
Evaluate: Critically evaluate the reliability of genomic surveillance data for public health decisions.(K,S)
Create: Translate genomic outbreak findings to create better methods for integrating data interpretation with public health decision-making. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Interpretation of genotypic and antimicrobial resistance data
Description: This topic focuses on interpreting antimicrobial resistance (AMR) data, with an emphasis on integrating genotypic predictions with broader AMR trends. Learners will explore how genomic data, such as resistance genes and mutations, are used to predict phenotypic resistance, as well as how these predictions align with surveillance data, clinical outcomes, and public health needs.
Short description: Explores the interpretation of genotypic predictions and AMR data to guide diagnostics, treatment, and public health strategies.
Remember: Define key terms and recall the genetic markers, tools and databases used for predicting antibiotic resistance from microbial genomes (K)
Understand: Explain how genomic features are interpreted to predict antibiotic resistance and their relationship to phenotypic resistance. (K)
Apply: Demonstrate the interpretation of genomic data to predict antibiotic resistance profiles.(S)
Analyse: Compare genotypic predictions with phenotypic resistance data to identify patterns or discrepancies. (KS)
Evaluate: Assess the accuracy and limitations of genotypic predictions in determining resistance phenotypes.(K)
Create: Develop frameworks for integrating genotypic and phenotypic AMR data into diagnostic or surveillance workflows. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic reporting standards for pathogen genomics and surveillance
Description: Involves establishing and following guidelines to ensure the consistent, accurate, and transparent reporting of genomic data related to pathogens
Short description: Guidelines to ensure the consistent, accurate, and transparent reporting of genomic data related to pathogens
Remember: State the key principles and terminology of reporting standards for pathogen genomics and surveillance.(K)
Understand: Discuss guidelines and protocols for genomic reporting in the context of pathogen genomics and surveillance. (K)
Apply: Apply standard guidelines to compile and report genomic data for pathogen surveillance.(K)
Analyse: Examine genomic reports to ensure compliance with reporting standards  (S).
Evaluate: Assess the effectiveness of genomic reporting standards for clarity and completeness, identifying areas for improvement.(K)
Create: Formulate or develop new or improved genomic reporting standards and enhance utility of pathogen genomics and surveillance data.(K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic and epidemiological data visualisation and presentation
Description: Genomic and epidemiological data visualisation and presentation involves creating clear, accurate, and informative visual representations of integrated genomic and epidemiological data. Use of various types of visualisations, tools, and best practices to effectively communicate complex data to diverse audiences, supporting public health decision-making, research, and broader stakeholder engagement.
Short description: Creating clear, accurate, and informative visual representations of integrated genomic and epidemiological data.
Remember: Define basic principles and effective methods for visualising and presenting genomic and epidemiological data. (K)
Understand: Discuss methods and tools for visualising genomic and epidemiological data, emphasing the importance of clear and effective visualisation in genomic epidemiology. (K)
Apply: Implement visualisation techniques to present genomic and epidemiological data clearly and informatively.(S)
Analyse: Examine the visualisations of genomic and epidemiological data.(K)
Evaluate: Assess the effectiveness and clarity of data visualisations, identifying areas for improvement (K)
Create: Design innovative ways to visualise and present genomic and epidemiological data, improving accuracy and clarity. (K,S)

Description: Decision-making integrates clinical and public health perspectives, ensuring genomic insights are applied effectively to guide decisions in clinical care and public health actions.

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Translational genomics from research to practice
Description: This topic focuses on bridging the gap between research and real-world applications by translating findings from genomic studies into actionable clinical and public health strategies. It explores how genomic research informs the development of diagnostic tools, therapeutic protocols, and policy frameworks. Learners will study examples of translational genomics, such as integrating resistance markers into clinical research or using genomic findings to refine public health guidelines for infection control.
Short description: Explores how genomic research findings are translated into actionable clinical and public health strategies.
Remember: Recall foundational concepts and methodologies that are applied in translating pathogen genomic research into clinical and public health practices (K)
Understand: Explain how genomic research findings improve patient management and disease surveillance (K)
Apply: Integrate genomic findings into clinical workflows to guide patient management and disease surveillance. (K)
Analyse: Analyse genomic research results to identify actionable findings, such as resistance profiles or other insights relevant to infectious disease management. (K)
Evaluate: Assess the relevance of genomic research findings for clinical or public health applications (e.g. use in developing AMR surveillance systems).(K)
Create: Translate genomic research findings into actionable policies and guidelines for integrating pathogen genomics nto clinical and public health (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic insights for clinical decision-making in infectious diseases
Description: This topic emphasises the application of genomic data to improve clinical decision-making for infectious diseases. It covers how genomic insights guide diagnosis, antimicrobial selection, and treatment customisation for individual patients. Learners will also explore examples such as integrating genomic diagnostics into hospital workflows, leveraging personalised medicine, and interpreting AMR profiles to refine therapy plans.
Short description: Focuses on using genomic data to guide diagnosis, treatment, and personalised care in infectious diseases.
Remember: List genomic approaches and recall how genomic data identifies pathogens and resistance mechanisms.(K)
Understand: Explain how pathogen genomic data informs diagnostics and patient management (K)
Apply: Use pathogen genomic data to inform diagnostics and patient management(S)
Analyse: Examine sequence results to link genomic profiles with clinical features.(K,S)
Evaluate: Evaluate impact of genomics-informed diagnostics and treatments on the management and outcomes of infectious diseases.(K)
Create: Design workflows that incorporate pathogen genomics to inform aspects of patient management. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic epidemiology for infectious disease control
Description: This topic examines how genomic data is applied to study pathogen transmission, investigate outbreaks, and inform public health responses. It focuses on genomic epidemiology tools and techniques, such as phylogenetic analyses and isolate clustering, to identify sources of infection and track pathogen evolution. Learners will study examples of genomic epidemiology in action, such as controlling hospital-associated infections or monitoring global pathogen spread.
Short description: Uses genomic data to trace pathogen transmission, investigate outbreaks, and inform public health responses.
Remember: Recall genomic methods used in outbreak investigations.(K)
Understand: Describe how genomic data helps trace infection sources.(K)
Apply: Use genomic data to map pathogen transmission in an outbreak (e.g. a healthcare facility).(S)
Analyse: Analyse genomic clusters to identify epidemiological trends at local or global level.(K,S)
Evaluate: Assess the accuracy of genomic epidemiology approaches in managing outbreaks (K)
Create: Develop frameworks and protocols for integrating genomic epidemiology into outbreak management and public health responses. (K)

(Revised) Domains and Topics: Genomic data for public health interventions for infectious diseases
Description: This topic focuses on using genomic data to design and implement public health interventions for infectious diseases. It highlights the role of genomics in AMR surveillance, outbreak preparedness, and long-term monitoring of pathogen dynamics. Learners will explore how genomic insights inform policies, such as infection control measures and resource allocation, and how they enhance global health strategies.
Short description: Covers the use of genomic data to design public health interventions and enhance infectious disease control strategies.
Remember: Recall genomic indicators relevant to public health interventions, such as resistance genes in priority pathogens monitored in surveillance programs.(K)
Understand: Explain the role of genomic data in shaping public health preparedness and interventions (e.g. how genomics informs vaccine development).(K)
Apply: Use pathogen genomic insights for public health interventions (e.g. tailor policies and infection control strategies, developing antimicrobial stewardship or vaccination programs). (S)
Analyse: Examine genomic trends to guide public health responses (e.g. prioritising intervention sites and informing targeted resource allocation).(K)
Evaluate: Measure genomic-based public health programme outcomes, and identify system gaps for continuous improvement.(K)
Create: Building scalable and resource-appropriate systems for genomic and epidemiological surveillance (K)

Description:
The Data Science in Pathogen Genomics competency framework defines the essential knowledge, skills, and abilities required for professionals working at the intersection of data science and pathogen genomics. It outlines core competencies in data management, computational analysis, machine learning, bioinformatics workflows, and interpretation of genomic data for pathogen surveillance, outbreak response, research and clinical applications.

The framework ensures that individuals can effectively handle large-scale genomic datasets, apply appropriate analytical methods, and generate meaningful insights. It also incorporates competencies in data integrity, reproducibility, automation, and computational efficiency, enabling professionals to make informed decisions and implement best practices in genomic data science.

Data curation for pathogen genomics involves collecting, validating, standardising, annotating, integrating, documenting, and managing genomic data to ensure its accuracy, consistency, and usability. This process is essential for facilitating meaningful analysis, research, and application of genomic data in understanding pathogens and managing infectious diseases.
Short description: Managing and standardising  data to ensure accuracy and usability, supporting meaningful analysis, research, and disease management
Remember: List data curation methods used in pathogen genomics. Recall terminologies used in data curation for pathogen genomics. (K)
Understand: Explain data curation processes used in pathogen genomics (K).
Apply: Curate, validate, and standardise pathogen genomic data using quality control and metadata integration tools and protocols. (S)
Analyse: Analyse curated genomic and linked data to determine its accuracy, consistency, and usability in downstream analysis (K,S)
Evaluate: Evaluate data curation processes and outputs, identifying areas for improvement to enhance data accuracy, reliability, and integration across datasets. (K)
Create: Design and improve data curation methods for use in pathogen genomics ensuring data quality and usability to advance research, enhance clinical diagnostics, and inform public health strategies. (K,S)

Description: Ethical, Legal, and Social Issues (ELSI) in Data Science for Pathogen Genomics involves addressing the complex and multifaceted concerns that arise when utilising genomic data to study pathogens. Ethical issues include ensuring informed consent, maintaining privacy and confidentiality of genetic information, and preventing misuse of data. Legal considerations involve adhering to regulations and guidelines governing data use, sharing, and storage, while ensuring compliance with international laws and policies. Social issues encompass the impact of genomic data on public health, the potential for stigmatisation or discrimination, and the equitable access to genomic technologies and benefits.
Short description: Accountable approaches to sample and data collection, genetic data use, and sharing that complies with laws and regulations while considering the impact on individuals.
Remember: Identify fundamental ethical, legal, and social issues in pathogen genomics and data sharing. (K)
Understand: Describe ethical and legal considerations for data use, sharing, storage, and social implications. (K)
Apply: Ensure ethical data collection, follow legal guidelines for data sharing and storage, and promote equitable access to genomic technologies.(S)
Analyse: Analyse the impact of ethical, legal, and social issues on pathogen genomics, assessing standards compliance and social implications. (K)
Evaluate: Critique policies on ethical, legal, and social issues in genomic data use balancing issues including rights of the  individual  and public interests. (K,S,A)
Create: Formulate ethical, legal, and social policies for storing and using pathogen genomic data to enhance public trust, prevent misuse, and ensure equitable benefits. (K,S)

Description: Data management for pathogen genomics involves organising, storing, and handling genomic data related to pathogens to ensure its integrity, accessibility, and security. This includes the processes of data collection, annotation, and curation to maintain high-quality datasets. Effective data management also entails implementing robust storage solutions and backup systems to protect against data loss. It also ensures compliance with legal and ethical standards for data sharing and privacy, and using bioinformatics tools to facilitate data analysis and integration.
Short description: Securely organising and storing data, ensuring accuracy, accessibility, and privacy.
Remember: Recall principles and terminologies of data collection, storage, retrieval and security. (K)
Understand: Explain the processes for organising, storing, and handling data. (K)
Apply: Utilise data management tools to collect, annotate, curate, store, and back up data (S)
Analyse: Validate data quality and organisation to meet research, clinical or public health needs. (K)
Evaluate: Evaluate data management strategies in pathogen genomics in various contexts. (K)
Create: Formulate new strategies to enhance data management in genomics to support for research, healthcare, and public health.(K)

Description: In pathogen genomics, metadata entails the supplementary information that provides context to the genomic data of pathogens. This includes details such as the date and location of sample collection, the host species, clinical data, sequencing technology used, and laboratory methods applied. Metadata helps researchers understand the conditions under which the genomic data was collected, enabling more accurate analyses and interpretations. It aids in tracking the origin and spread of pathogens, comparing data across different studies, and ensuring data quality and reproducibility. Metadata focuses on theoretical knowledge about the concept, structure, and significance of metadata
Short description: Supplementary information providing context, including details like collection date, location, methods used.
Remember: List key elements of sample metadata required for genomics (e.g., source, collection date, conditions). (K)
Understand: Explain the importance of metadata collection in ensuring sample traceability and reproducibility.(K)
Apply: Apply appropriate methods and standards to record sample metadata systematically.(S)
Analyse: Review collected sample metadata to identify gaps, inconsistencies, or errors that could affect data interpretation.(K)
Evaluate: Assess the quality and completeness of metadata collection protocols to ensure they align with best practices and support downstream analyses.(K)
Create: Design a metadata collection framework tailored to specific microbiological, molecular, or genomic studies(K,S)

Description: This topic focuses on the principles, practices, and challenges of sharing genomic data in the context of infectious diseases and pathogen genomics. Data sharing ensures that genomic insights are accessible to researchers, clinicians, and public health stakeholders worldwide, enabling collaborative efforts to combat emerging infectious diseases, antimicrobial resistance (AMR), and outbreaks. It emphasizes the need for interoperability, ethical compliance, and adherence to global data-sharing frameworks. Topics include open-access repositories, data standards, and the integration of metadata with genomic data for effective analysis and application.
Short description: Distribution and exchange of data using standardised platforms, protocols and adherence to ELSIs
Remember: List the key platforms and global repositories used for sharing pathogen genomic data. (K)
Understand: Explain the standards, protocols, and legal and ethical considerations for data sharing.(K)
Apply: Utilise data sharing platforms for standardised data submission and access, ensuring detailed metadata and ethical compliance. (S)
Analyse: Examine shared genomic datasets to identify trends or gaps (KS)
Evaluate: Critically evaluate data-sharing practices, platforms, and legal frameworks for genomic data, including assessing databases for completeness and ethical compliance. (K, S)
Create: Develop data-sharing frameworks or policies to enhance collaboration and ensure ethical compliance.(K)

Description: Data repositories and access for pathogen genomics involve the collection, storage, and sharing of genomic data from various pathogens. These repositories provide a centralised location where researchers can submit, retrieve, and analyse genetic sequences. They ensure data is accessible to the global scientific community, facilitating collaboration and advancing research on pathogen evolution, transmission, and control. Effective data management practices, such as standardised formats and secure access protocols, are crucial for maintaining the integrity and usability of the genomic data stored in these repositories.
Short description: Centralized systems where information or data is securely stored, managed, and made accessible for users to retrieve, share, and analyse.
Remember: List data repositories relevant to pathogen genomics, and recall the purpose and basic functions of data repositories in pathogen genomics. (K)
Understand: Explain processes of collecting, storing, and accessing data in repositories. (K)
Apply: Use data repositories to retrieve pathogen genomic sequences.(S)
Analyse: Analyse the suitability of repositories for storing and providing access to pathogen genomic data. (K)
Evaluate: Evaluate repositories for effectiveness, accessibility, user-friendliness, and the impact of standardised data management in research and healthcare.(K)
Create: Create or improve a data repository to enhance the storage, access, and security of pathogen genomic data.(K,S)

Description: Explores the application of data science principles to pathogen genomics, focusing on advanced computational methods for handling large-scale genomic datasets. It covers key areas such as data processing, AI/ML integration, cloud computing, and workflow automation, enabling researchers to manage, analyse, and visualise genomic data efficiently. Beyond traditional bioinformatics, this theme incorporates broader data science techniques, including machine learning for predictive modelling, scalable cloud-based pipelines, and automated data workflows to enhance reproducibility and efficiency. The emphasis is on leveraging computational tools to optimise pathogen genomic research and support data-driven decision-making in research and public health.
Short description: Specialised software to efficiently analyse, process, and visualise large datasets, automating complex tasks. Broader than just genomics, this theme incorporates data science principles, automation, and big data handling, aimed at working with pathogen genomics at scale.
Remember: Identify commonly used data science tools, programming languages, and workflow management systems for large-scale pathogen genomic data processing. (K)
Understand: Explain how data tools and workflows support efficient data handling, automation, and reproducibility in pathogen genomics, from raw data processing to visualisation. (K)
Apply: Use data science tools such as Python, R, or cloud-based platforms to clean, integrate, and process pathogen genomic datasets, ensuring reproducibility and efficiency.(K)
Analyse: Compare and interpret different computational frameworks for pathogen genomic data management by assessing their performance, scalability, and impact on various applications, breaking down their components to identify patterns, strengths, and weaknesses in how they handle genomic data.(K)
Evaluate: Critically assess the effectiveness of data science workflows in pathogen genomics by evaluating automation, data integrity, and computational efficiency, making judgments on their suitability for different applications and justifying the most effective workflow based on these criteria.. (K)
Create: Optimise a genomic data workflow by integrating and customising  tools to enhance data analysis and interpretation (K,S)

Description: Develops cross-cutting competencies and skills enable professionals to work collaboratively, communicate findings, and engage stakeholders effectively.

This topic focuses on developing effective verbal, non-verbal, and written communication skills tailored to the context of pathogen genomics. It includes strategies for delivering impactful presentations, engaging diverse audiences, and disseminating complex scientific concepts in accessible formats. Learners will also explore how to adapt communication styles for various audiences.
Short description: Covers strategies for effective communication and presentation in pathogen genomics.
Remember: Appreciate importance of clear communication of pathogen genomics related information among the stakeholders including non-technical audiences (A)
Understand: Explain the importance of tailoring communication styles for different audiences and describe how to present pathogen genomics concepts in accessible formats. (K)
Apply: Apply effective verbal, non-verbal, and written techniques to clearly convey pathogen genomics-related information to diverse stakeholders, including non-technical audiences, clinicians, and policymakers, using appropriate strategies (S)
Analyse: Search for efficient ways of  communicating pathogen genomics related information among the stakeholders along the genomics pipeline, including different non technical audiences and clinicians, policy makers, community members (K)
Evaluate: Critically assess the effectiveness of different communication strategies for disseminating pathogen genomics findings and justify the choice of specific methods based on audience needs and content complexity. (K)
Create: Develop a communication plan incorporating verbal, non-verbal, and written strategies, and design an engaging presentation or outreach material to effectively convey complex pathogen genomics concepts to diverse audiences. (K)

Description: This topic emphasizes fostering an inclusive and equitable environment in genomics research and public health initiatives. Learners will explore strategies for integrating EDI principles into program design, stakeholder engagement, and team dynamics to ensure diverse perspectives are represented and underserved communities are included in genomics-based research and applications.
Short description: Focuses on promoting equity, diversity, and inclusion in pathogen genomics.
Remember: Think of different perspectives and needs of various  stakeholders involved in pathogen genomics enhanced healthcare (A)
Understand: Recognize importance of considering different perspectives and needs of various community stakeholders involved in pathogen genomics enhanced healthcare (A)
Apply: Demonstrate  inclusive attitude towards different perspectives and needs of various community stakeholders involved in pathogen genomics enhanced healthcare (A)
Analyse: Comparing the impact of verbal, non-verbal, and written methods to determine their effectiveness in engaging various stakeholders, while individualising and supporting their diverse perspectives and needs in genomics-enhanced applications and healthcare. (A,K))
Evaluate: Weigh up different EDI strategies to determine how to best serve the perspectives and needs  of various community stakeholders involved in pathogen genomics enhanced healthcare (K)
Create: Define appropriate EDI strategies and approaches to best suit different perspectives and needs of various community stakeholders involved in pathogen genomics enhanced healthcare (K)

Description: This topic highlights the importance of building professional networks and fostering collaborative relationships in pathogen genomics. Learners will develop skills for establishing partnerships across disciplines, institutions, and geographic boundaries to enhance research, diagnostics, and public health applications. Emphasis is placed on leveraging global networks to address challenges such as AMR and emerging infectious diseases.
Short description: Explores strategies for networking and fostering collaboration in genomics.
Remember: Appreciate the importance of networking and belonging to different social learning spaces for development of new abilities (K)
Understand: Recognise importance and ways of integrating into different pathogen genomics communities  and networks in order to enhance own practice (S)
Apply: Integrate effectively into different pathogen genomics communities of practice and networks in order to enhance own practice (S)
Analyse: Determine the best ways of integrating into different networks in order to enhance own practice and contribute to different pathogen genomics communities (S)
Evaluate: Assess the impact of the participation in different networks on results achieved in own practice (K)
Create: Establish own pathogen genomics networks/CoPs  to enable the exchange and application of best practices in pathogen genomics (K,S)

Description: This topic focuses on mentorship and leadership skills to support professional development and capacity building in pathogen genomics. Learners will explore how to mentor trainees and early-career professionals, foster team growth, and lead initiatives that address infectious disease challenges. Leadership principles will include fostering innovation, promoting inclusivity, and driving impactful genomic research and interventions.
Short description: Covers mentorship and leadership skills for advancing pathogen genomics capacity.
Remember: Anticipate how one own values, beliefs and behaviours affect own practice and can be managed to meet mentee’s objectives. (A)
Understand: Establish and maintain the expectations and boundaries of the mentoring contract with the mentee (ex abides by the code of ethics) (S) (A)
Apply: Skilfully build and maintain an effective relationship with the mentee (S)
Analyse: Bring about insight and learning by working with the mentee. (K)
Evaluate: Gathers and analyses information on the effectiveness of their practice demonstrating to mentee importance of establishing a culture of evaluation of outcomes.(K)
Create: Applies creative models and tools, techniques and ideas beyond the core communication skills in order to bring about insight and learning with mentee (K)

Description: This topic combines the principles of scientific writing and effective reporting to communicate pathogen genomics findings to diverse audiences, including researchers, policymakers, public health professionals, and the general public. Learners will explore methods for creating high-quality, structured publications and reports that adhere to agreed standards. Emphasis is placed on ensuring clarity, accuracy, accessibility, and the relevance of genomics data to diagnostics, research, and public health action. Additionally, learners will gain skills in evaluating and improving reporting standards and methods to advance the field of pathogen genomics.
Short description: Focuses on scientific writing and reporting for diverse genomics audiences.
Remember: Recall the processes, formats, and standards used to present pathogen genomics findings in structured publications or reports. (K)
Understand: Explain the processes and importance of adhering to agreed standards in scientific writing and reporting genomics data (K)
Apply: Apply appropriate methods and standards to create high-quality reports and publications for specific audiences and stakeholders (K)
Analyse: Distinguish high-quality published research data, methods and scientific results, and promote them to other colleagues/researchers.(K)
